FacilityName: HWRT Terminal - N  Little Rock, LLC

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



1.0 FACILITY DESCRIPTION

The HWRT Terminal - N. Little Rock, LLC (HWRT) facility is a terminal for the storage and distribution of various fuels. Petroleum products (i.e. gasoline and diesel) are received by pipeline.  Transport trucks deliver ethanol, biodiesel, and other additives to the facility.  Transport trucks then deliver the products to the facility's customers.  HWRT has a 30,000-gallon butane storage tank and a butane injection process at the facility.



Butane has been identified by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) as a regulated substance subject to Section 112 (r) of the Clean Air Act, which requires the preparation of this Risk Management Plan (RMP).  HWRT is also subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) process safety management standard and hence, it is subject to the requirements of a Program Level 3 Risk Management Plan.



The initial construction of the terminal facility was completed in 1965, which included construction of Tanks NLR-201 through NLR-204. Additional tanks were constructed later.  HWRT purchased the terminal from Crown Central, LLC in 2004.



The facility is located at 2626 Central Airport Road in North Little Rock, Arkansas.  The immediate vicinity is sparsely populated and the facility is in an industrial area near Interstate Highway 40.  The facility has several fuel and additive storage tanks having capacities ranging from 200 gallons to 3.528 million gallons.  Each of these tanks is provided with adequate secondary containment except for butane storage tank for which secondary containment is not necessary as butane is a gas at ambient conditions.



The butane injection process at the facility is fairly simple. Liquefied butane gas is delivered by tank trucks and pumped into the butane tank.  Butane is stored under ambient temperatures and under pressure.  Butane is injected into gasoline by pumping it into the pipeline as the gasoline is being delivered to H

butane tank and supporting equipment was installed and tested in September, 2006.  An inspector from the Liquefied Petroleum Gas Board inspected the process, pressure-tested the tank, and approved the installation on September 18, 2006, prior to HWRT initiating the butane process at this facility.



In addition, HWRT hires an experienced, knowledgeable, outside contractor to perform regular inspections of the butane system.  This inspection includes evaluating the condition of the tank, piping, and supports, checking internal valves, pressure release valves, emergency shut-off valves and cables, pressure gauge, and liquid pump.



4.0 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

This facility has not had a reportable release of butane or any regulated substance as defined in 40 CFR 68.3 and 68.130 (or an OSHA highly hazardous chemical as defined in 40 CFR 29.1910(b)) within the last five years.



5.0 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The facility emergency response programs include FRP and SPCC Plans.  The FRP includes information regarding specific actions to be taken in response to an accidental release of butane, procedures to inform the public about a release, and first aid and toxicity information regarding butane.  All employees working with butane are trained in handling flammable materials and are provided with an annual refresher training.  This plan has been coordinated with the Pulaski County and North Little Rock LEPCs.  The telephone number for the North Little Rock LEPC is 501-340-5365.



6.0 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Last PHA conducted on August 26, 2021.  All previous recommendations were reviewed and are still relevant. At present, there are no additional planned changes to improve safety.



7.0 MODEL USED TO PERFORM WORST-CASE AND ALTERNATE SCENARIO

Facility had used EPA's RMP* Comp* software was used to derive the end-point distances.  A windshield survey of the regions indicated that several of the residential structures have been removed or are uninhabit

able.  The survey found that only 8 structures remained. A conservative estimate of 4 persons per structure was utilized and the estimated population was revised to 32 residents.  No additional commercial facilities have been added since the last update.
